subject: Politics
title: The Korean Peninsula
description: A 60-second lesson on The Korean Peninsula.

hook.text: North and South Korea are still technically at war. The 1953 armistice was a pause, not a peace treaty.

buildup.text: Korea was divided after World War II. The North became communist; the South became democratic and capitalist.

discovery.text: North Korea has nuclear weapons and missiles that can reach the US mainland. Deterrence is all that keeps peace.

twist.text: South Korea's economy is 50 times larger than the North's. Reunification would cost trillions and take decades.

climax.text: China props up North Korea to prevent a unified, US-allied Korea on its border. Geopolitics keeps the divide alive.

punchline.text: Korea is still divided by Cold War logic. The war never officially ended.

quiz.question: Why does China support North Korea?
options: To prevent a unified, US-allied Korea on its border
Because they share identical political systems
China depends on North Korean trade
